â
'''Pidgin''' (formerly named '''Gaim''') is a multi-platform [[instant messaging]] [[client (computing)|client]], based on a [[library (computing)|library]] named '''libpurple'''. Libpurple has support for many commonly used instant messaging [[Protocol (computing)|protocols]], allowing the user to log into various different services from one application.
+
'''Pidgin''' (formerly named '''Gaim''') is an [[open-source]] multi-platform [[instant messaging]] [[client (computing)|client]], based on a [[library (computing)|library]] named '''libpurple'''. Libpurple has support for many commonly used instant messaging [[Protocol (computing)|protocols]], allowing the user to log into various different services from one application.
â
The number of Pidgin users was estimated to be over 3 million in 2007.<ref>[http://www.pcworld.idg.com.au/index.php/id;1641709366;pp;1;fp;2;fpid;4 Luke Schierer discusses Pidgin, Open source and life]. Interview by [[PC World (magazine)#Countries|PC World]] Australia, 10 October 2007</ref> Both Pidgin and libpurple are [[free software]], released under the terms of the [[GNU General Public License]].
+
The number of Pidgin users was estimated to be over 3 million in 2007.<ref>[http://www.pcworld.idg.com.au/index.php/id;1641709366;pp;1;fp;2;fpid;4 Luke Schierer discusses Pidgin, Open source and life]. Interview by [[PC World (magazine)#Countries|PC World]] Australia, 10 October 2007</ref>
